b'---
layout: blog
title: "PodSecurityPolicy Deprecation: Past, Present, and Future"
date: 2021-04-06
slug: podsecuritypolicy-deprecation-past-present-and-future
---
**Author:** Tabitha Sable (Kubernetes SIG Security)

{{% pageinfo color="primary" %}}
**Update:** *With the release of Kubernetes v1.25, PodSecurityPolicy has been removed.* *You can read more information about the removal of PodSecurityPolicy in the [Kubernetes 1.25 release notes](/blog/2022/08/23/kubernetes-v1-25-release/#pod-security-changes).*
{{% /pageinfo %}}

PodSecurityPolicy (PSP) is being deprecated in Kubernetes 1.21, to be released later this week. This starts the countdown to its removal, but doesn\xe2\x80\x99t change anything else. PodSecurityPolicy will continue to be fully functional for several more releases before being removed completely. In the meantime, we are developing a replacement for PSP that covers key use cases more easily and sustainably.

What are Pod Security Policies? Why did we need them? Why are they going away, and what\xe2\x80\x99s next? How does this affect you? These key questions come to mind as we prepare to say goodbye to PSP, so let\xe2\x80\x99s walk through them together. We\xe2\x80\x99ll start with an overview of how features get removed from Kubernetes.

## What does deprecation mean in Kubernetes?

Whenever a Kubernetes feature is set to go away, our [deprecation policy](/docs/reference/using-api/deprecation-policy/) is our guide. First the feature is marked as deprecated, then after enough time has passed, it can finally be removed.

Kubernetes 1.21 starts the deprecation process for PodSecurityPolicy. As with all feature deprecations, PodSecurityPolicy will continue to be fully functional for several more releases. The current plan is to remove PSP from Kubernetes in the 1.25 release.

Until then, PSP is still PSP. There will be at least a year during which the newest Kubernetes releases will still support PSP, and nearly two years until PSP will pass fully out of all supported Kubernetes versions.

## What is PodSecurityPolicy?

[PodSecurityPolicy](/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-policy/) is a built-in [admission controller](/blog/2019/03/21/a-guide-to-kubernetes-admission-controllers/) that allows a cluster administrator to control security-sensitive aspects of the Pod specification. 

First, one or more PodSecurityPolicy resources are created in a cluster to define the requirements Pods must meet. Then, RBAC rules are created to control which PodSecurityPolicy applies to a given pod. If a pod meets the requirements of its PSP, it will be admitted to the cluster as usual. In some cases, PSP can also modify Pod fields, effectively creating new defaults for those fields. If a Pod does not meet the PSP requirements, it is rejected, and cannot run. 

One more important thing to know about PodSecurityPolicy: it\xe2\x80\x99s not the same as [PodSecurityContext](/docs/reference/kubernetes-api/workload-resources/pod-v1/#security-context).

A part of the Pod specification, PodSecurityContext (and its per-container counterpart `SecurityContext`) is the collection of fields that specify many of the security-relevant settings for a Pod. The security context dictates to the kubelet and container runtime how the Pod should actually be run. In contrast, the PodSecurityPolicy only constrains (or defaults) the values that may be set on the security context.

The deprecation of PSP does not affect PodSecurityContext in any way.

## Why did we need PodSecurityPolicy?

In Kubernetes, we define resources such as Deployments, StatefulSets, and Services that represent the building blocks of software applications. The various controllers inside a Kubernetes cluster react to these resources, creating further Kubernetes resources or configuring some software or hardware to accomplish our goals.

In most Kubernetes clusters, RBAC (Role-Based Access Control) [rules](/docs/reference/access-authn-authz/rbac/#role-and-clusterrole) control access to these resources. `list`, `get`, `create`, `edit`, and `delete` are the sorts of API operations that RBAC cares about, but _RBAC does not consider what settings are being put into the resources it controls_. For example, a Pod can be almost anything from a simple webserver to a privileged command prompt offering full access to the underlying server node and all the data. It\xe2\x80\x99s all the same to RBAC: a Pod is a Pod is a Pod.

To control what sorts of settings are allowed in the resources defined in your cluster, you need Admission Control in addition to RBAC. Since Kubernetes 1.3, PodSecurityPolicy has been the built-in way to do that for security-related Pod fields. Using PodSecurityPolicy, you can prevent \xe2\x80\x9ccreate Pod\xe2\x80\x9d from automatically meaning \xe2\x80\x9croot on every cluster node,\xe2\x80\x9d without needing to deploy additional external admission controllers.

## Why is PodSecurityPolicy going away?

In the years since PodSecurityPolicy was first introduced, we have realized that PSP has some serious usability problems that can\xe2\x80\x99t be addressed without making breaking changes.

The way PSPs are applied to Pods has proven confusing to nearly everyone that has attempted to use them. It is easy to accidentally grant broader permissions than intended, and difficult to inspect which PSP(s) apply in a given situation. The \xe2\x80\x9cchanging Pod defaults\xe2\x80\x9d feature can be handy, but is only supported for certain Pod settings and it\xe2\x80\x99s not obvious when they will or will not apply to your Pod. Without a \xe2\x80\x9cdry run\xe2\x80\x9d or audit mode, it\xe2\x80\x99s impractical to retrofit PSP to existing clusters safely, and it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible for PSP to ever be enabled by default.

For more information about these and other PSP difficulties, check out SIG Auth\xe2\x80\x99s KubeCon NA 2019 Maintainer Track session video: {{< youtube "SFtHRmPuhEw?start=953" youtube-quote-sm >}}

Today, you\xe2\x80\x99re not limited only to deploying PSP or writing your own custom admission controller. Several external admission controllers are available that incorporate lessons learned from PSP to provide a better user experience. [K-Rail](https://github.com/cruise-automation/k-rail), [Kyverno](https://github.com/kyverno/kyverno/), and [OPA/Gatekeeper](https://github.com/open-policy-agent/gatekeeper/) are all well-known, and each has its fans.

Although there are other good options available now, we believe there is still value in having a built-in admission controller available as a choice for users. With this in mind, we turn toward building what\xe2\x80\x99s next, inspired by the lessons learned from PSP.

## What\xe2\x80\x99s next?

Kubernetes SIG Security, SIG Auth, and a diverse collection of other community members have been working together for months to ensure that what\xe2\x80\x99s coming next is going to be awesome. We have developed a Kubernetes Enhancement Proposal ([KEP 2579](https://github.com/kubernetes/enhancements/issues/2579)) and a prototype for a new feature, currently being called by the temporary name "PSP Replacement Policy." We are targeting an Alpha release in Kubernetes 1.22.

PSP Replacement Policy starts with the realization that since there is a robust ecosystem of external admission controllers already available, PSP\xe2\x80\x99s replacement doesn\xe2\x80\x99t need to be all things to all people. Simplicity of deployment and adoption is the key advantage a built-in admission controller has compared to an external webhook, so we have focused on how to best utilize that advantage.

PSP Replacement Policy is designed to be as simple as practically possible while providing enough flexibility to really be useful in production at scale. It has soft rollout features to enable retrofitting it to existing clusters, and is configurable enough that it can eventually be active by default. It can be deactivated partially or entirely, to coexist with external admission controllers for advanced use cases.

## What does this mean for you?

What this all means for you depends on your current PSP situation. If you\xe2\x80\x99re already using PSP, there\xe2\x80\x99s plenty of time to plan your next move. Please review the PSP Replacement Policy KEP and think about how well it will suit your use case.

If you\xe2\x80\x99re making extensive use of the flexibility of PSP with numerous PSPs and complex binding rules, you will likely find the simplicity of PSP Replacement Policy too limiting. Use the next year to evaluate the other admission controller choices in the ecosystem. There are resources available to ease this transition, such as the [Gatekeeper Policy Library](https://github.com/open-policy-agent/gatekeeper-library).

If your use of PSP is relatively simple, with a few policies and straightforward binding to service accounts in each namespace, you will likely find PSP Replacement Policy to be a good match for your needs. Evaluate your PSPs compared to the Kubernetes [Pod Security Standards](/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-standards/) to get a feel for where you\xe2\x80\x99ll be able to use the Restricted, Baseline, and Privileged policies. Please follow along with or contribute to the KEP and subsequent development, and try out the Alpha release of PSP Replacement Policy when it becomes available.

If you\xe2\x80\x99re just beginning your PSP journey, you will save time and effort by keeping it simple. You can approximate the functionality of PSP Replacement Policy today by using the Pod Security Standards\xe2\x80\x99 PSPs. If you set the cluster default by binding a Baseline or Restricted policy to the `system:serviceaccounts` group, and then make a more-permissive policy available as needed in certain Namespaces [using ServiceAccount bindings](/docs/concepts/policy/pod-security-policy/#run-another-pod), you will avoid many of the PSP pitfalls and have an easy migration to PSP Replacement Policy. If your needs are much more complex than this, your effort is probably better spent adopting one of the more fully-featured external admission controllers mentioned above.

We\xe2\x80\x99re dedicated to making Kubernetes the best container orchestration tool we can, and sometimes that means we need to remove longstanding features to make space for better things to come. When that happens, the Kubernetes deprecation policy ensures you have plenty of time to plan your next move. In the case of PodSecurityPolicy, several options are available to suit a range of needs and use cases. Start planning ahead now for PSP\xe2\x80\x99s eventual removal, and please consider contributing to its replacement! Happy securing!

**Acknowledgment:** It takes a wonderful group to make wonderful software. Thanks are due to everyone who has contributed to the PSP replacement effort, especially (in alphabetical order) Tim Allclair, Ian Coldwater, and Jordan Liggitt. It\xe2\x80\x99s been a joy to work with y\xe2\x80\x99all on this.
'

title: Pod Security Policies
content_type: concept
weight: 30
---

<!-- overview -->

{{% alert title="Removed feature" color="warning" %}}
PodSecurityPolicy was [deprecated](/blog/2021/04/08/kubernetes-1-21-release-announcement/#podsecuritypolicy-deprecation)
in Kubernetes v1.21, and removed from Kubernetes in v1.25.
{{% /alert %}}

Instead of using PodSecurityPolicy, you can enforce similar restrictions on Pods using
either or both:

- [Pod Security Admission](/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-admission/)
- a 3rd party admission plugin, that you deploy and configure yourself

For a migration guide, see [Migrate from PodSecurityPolicy to the Built-In PodSecurity Admission Controller](/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/migrate-from-psp/).
For more information on the removal of this API,
see [PodSecurityPolicy Deprecation: Past, Present, and Future](/blog/2021/04/06/podsecuritypolicy-deprecation-past-present-and-future/).

If you are not running Kubernetes v{{< skew currentVersion >}}, check the documentation for
your version of Kubernetes.
'

<!--
title: "PodSecurityPolicy Deprecation: Past, Present, and Future"
-->

<!--
**Author:** Tabitha Sable (Kubernetes SIG Security)
-->
\xe4\xbd\x9c\xe8\x80\x85\xef\xbc\x9aTabitha Sable\xef\xbc\x88Kubernetes SIG Security\xef\xbc\x89

<!--
PodSecurityPolicy (PSP) is being deprecated in Kubernetes 1.21, to be released later this week.
This starts the countdown to its removal, but doesn\xe2\x80\x99t change anything else.
PodSecurityPolicy will continue to be fully functional for several more releases before being removed completely.
In the meantime, we are developing a replacement for PSP that covers key use cases more easily and sustainably.
-->
PodSecurityPolicy (PSP) \xe5\x9c\xa8 Kubernetes 1.21 \xe4\xb8\xad\xe8\xa2\xab\xe5\xbc\x83\xe7\x94\xa8\xe3\x80\x82<!--to be released later this week\xe8\xbf\x99\xe5\x8f\xa5\xe6\x84\x9f\xe8\xa7\x89\xe6\xb2\xa1\xe5\xbf\x85\xe8\xa6\x81\xe7\xbf\xbb\xe8\xaf\x91\xef\xbc\x8c\xe9\x9d\x9e\xe6\xbc\x8f\xe8\xaf\x91-->
PSP \xe6\x97\xa5\xe5\x90\x8e\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe8\xa2\xab\xe7\xa7\xbb\xe9\x99\xa4\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbd\x86\xe7\x9b\xae\xe5\x89\x8d\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe6\x94\xb9\xe5\x8f\x98\xe4\xbb\xbb\xe4\xbd\x95\xe5\x85\xb6\xe4\xbb\x96\xe5\x86\x85\xe5\xae\xb9\xe3\x80\x82\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe7\xa7\xbb\xe9\x99\xa4\xe4\xb9\x8b\xe5\x89\x8d\xef\xbc\x8cPSP \xe5\xb0\x86\xe7\xbb\xa7\xe7\xbb\xad\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe5\x90\x8e\xe7\xbb\xad\xe5\xa4\x9a\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe7\x89\x88\xe6\x9c\xac\xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\xae\x8c\xe5\x85\xa8\xe6\xad\xa3\xe5\xb8\xb8\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe3\x80\x82
\xe4\xb8\x8e\xe6\xad\xa4\xe5\x90\x8c\xe6\x97\xb6\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\x88\x91\xe4\xbb\xac\xe6\xad\xa3\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe5\xbc\x80\xe5\x8f\x91 PSP \xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x9b\xbf\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe5\x93\x81\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\xb8\x8c\xe6\x9c\x9b\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe8\xbd\xbb\xe6\x9d\xbe\xe3\x80\x81\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe6\x8c\x81\xe7\xbb\xad\xe5\x9c\xb0\xe8\xa6\x86\xe7\x9b\x96\xe5\x85\xb3\xe9\x94\xae\xe7\x94\xa8\xe4\xbe\x8b\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
What are Pod Security Policies? Why did we need them? Why are they going away, and what\xe2\x80\x99s next?
How does this affect you? These key questions come to mind as we prepare to say goodbye to PSP,
so let\xe2\x80\x99s walk through them together. We\xe2\x80\x99ll start with an overview of how features get removed from Kubernetes.
-->
\xe4\xbb\x80\xe4\xb9\x88\xe6\x98\xaf PSP\xef\xbc\x9f\xe4\xb8\xba\xe4\xbb\x80\xe4\xb9\x88\xe9\x9c\x80\xe8\xa6\x81 PSP\xef\xbc\x9f\xe4\xb8\xba\xe4\xbb\x80\xe4\xb9\x88\xe8\xa6\x81\xe5\xbc\x83\xe7\x94\xa8\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\x9c\xaa\xe6\x9d\xa5\xe5\x8f\x88\xe5\xb0\x86\xe5\xa6\x82\xe4\xbd\x95\xe5\x8f\x91\xe5\xb1\x95\xef\xbc\x9f
\xe8\xbf\x99\xe5\xaf\xb9\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe6\x9c\x89\xe4\xbb\x80\xe4\xb9\x88\xe5\xbd\xb1\xe5\x93\x8d\xef\xbc\x9f\xe5\xbd\x93\xe6\x88\x91\xe4\xbb\xac\xe5\x87\x86\xe5\xa4\x87\xe5\x91\x8a\xe5\x88\xab PSP\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xba\x9b\xe5\x85\xb3\xe9\x94\xae\xe9\x97\xae\xe9\xa2\x98\xe6\xb5\xae\xe7\x8e\xb0\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe8\x84\x91\xe6\xb5\xb7\xe4\xb8\xad\xef\xbc\x8c
\xe6\x89\x80\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe8\xae\xa9\xe6\x88\x91\xe4\xbb\xac\xe4\xb8\x80\xe8\xb5\xb7\xe6\x9d\xa5\xe8\xae\xa8\xe8\xae\xba\xe5\x90\xa7\xe3\x80\x82\xe6\x9c\xac\xe6\x96\x87\xe9\xa6\x96\xe5\x85\x88\xe6\xa6\x82\xe8\xbf\xb0 Kubernetes \xe5\xa6\x82\xe4\xbd\x95\xe7\xa7\xbb\xe9\x99\xa4\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xba\x9b\xe7\x89\xb9\xe6\x80\xa7\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
## What does deprecation mean in Kubernetes?
-->
## Kubernetes \xe4\xb8\xad\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xbc\x83\xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xbb\x80\xe4\xb9\x88\xe6\x84\x8f\xe6\x80\x9d\xef\xbc\x9f

<!--
Whenever a Kubernetes feature is set to go away, our [deprecation policy](/docs/reference/using-api/deprecation-policy/)
is our guide. First the feature is marked as deprecated, then after enough time has passed, it can finally be removed.
-->
\xe6\xaf\x8f\xe5\xbd\x93 Kubernetes \xe5\x86\xb3\xe5\xae\x9a\xe5\xbc\x83\xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\x9f\x90\xe9\xa1\xb9\xe7\x89\xb9\xe6\x80\xa7\xe6\x97\xb6\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\x88\x91\xe4\xbb\xac\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe9\x81\xb5\xe5\xbe\xaa[\xe5\xbc\x83\xe7\x94\xa8\xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5](/zh-cn/docs/reference/using-api/deprecation-policy/)\xe3\x80\x82
\xe9\xa6\x96\xe5\x85\x88\xe5\xb0\x86\xe8\xaf\xa5\xe7\x89\xb9\xe6\x80\xa7\xe6\xa0\x87\xe8\xae\xb0\xe4\xb8\xba\xe5\xb7\xb2\xe5\xbc\x83\xe7\x94\xa8\xef\xbc\x8c\xe7\x84\xb6\xe5\x90\x8e\xe7\xbb\x8f\xe8\xbf\x87\xe8\xb6\xb3\xe5\xa4\x9f\xe9\x95\xbf\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x97\xb6\xe9\x97\xb4\xe5\x90\x8e\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\x9c\x80\xe7\xbb\x88\xe5\xb0\x86\xe5\x85\xb6\xe7\xa7\xbb\xe9\x99\xa4\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
Kubernetes 1.21 starts the deprecation process for PodSecurityPolicy. As with all feature deprecations,
PodSecurityPolicy will continue to be fully functional for several more releases.
The current plan is to remove PSP from Kubernetes in the 1.25 release.
-->
Kubernetes 1.21 \xe5\x90\xaf\xe5\x8a\xa8\xe4\xba\x86 PodSecurityPolicy \xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xbc\x83\xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\xb5\x81\xe7\xa8\x8b\xe3\x80\x82\xe4\xb8\x8e\xe5\xbc\x83\xe7\x94\xa8\xe4\xbb\xbb\xe4\xbd\x95\xe5\x85\xb6\xe4\xbb\x96\xe5\x8a\x9f\xe8\x83\xbd\xe4\xb8\x80\xe6\xa0\xb7\xef\xbc\x8c
PodSecurityPolicy \xe5\xb0\x86\xe7\xbb\xa7\xe7\xbb\xad\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe5\x90\x8e\xe7\xbb\xad\xe5\x87\xa0\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe7\x89\x88\xe6\x9c\xac\xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\xae\x8c\xe5\x85\xa8\xe6\xad\xa3\xe5\xb8\xb8\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe3\x80\x82\xe7\x9b\xae\xe5\x89\x8d\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xae\xa1\xe5\x88\x92\xe6\x98\xaf\xe5\x9c\xa8 1.25 \xe7\x89\x88\xe6\x9c\xac\xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\xb0\x86\xe5\x85\xb6\xe7\xa7\xbb\xe9\x99\xa4\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
Until then, PSP is still PSP. There will be at least a year during which the newest Kubernetes releases will
still support PSP, and nearly two years until PSP will pass fully out of all supported Kubernetes versions.
-->
\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe5\xbd\xbb\xe5\xba\x95\xe7\xa7\xbb\xe9\x99\xa4\xe4\xb9\x8b\xe5\x89\x8d\xef\xbc\x8cPSP \xe4\xbb\x8d\xe7\x84\xb6\xe6\x98\xaf PSP\xe3\x80\x82\xe8\x87\xb3\xe5\xb0\x91\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe6\x9c\xaa\xe6\x9d\xa5\xe4\xb8\x80\xe5\xb9\xb4\xe6\x97\xb6\xe9\x97\xb4\xe5\x86\x85\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\x9c\x80\xe6\x96\xb0\xe7\x9a\x84 Kubernetes
\xe7\x89\x88\xe6\x9c\xac\xe4\xbb\x8d\xe5\xb0\x86\xe7\xbb\xa7\xe7\xbb\xad\xe6\x94\xaf\xe6\x8c\x81 PSP\xe3\x80\x82\xe5\xa4\xa7\xe7\xba\xa6\xe4\xb8\xa4\xe5\xb9\xb4\xe4\xb9\x8b\xe5\x90\x8e\xef\xbc\x8cPSP \xe6\x89\x8d\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe5\x8f\x97\xe6\x94\xaf\xe6\x8c\x81\xe7\x9a\x84 Kubernetes \xe7\x89\x88\xe6\x9c\xac\xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\xbd\xbb\xe5\xba\x95\xe6\xb6\x88\xe5\xa4\xb1\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
## What is PodSecurityPolicy?
-->
## \xe4\xbb\x80\xe4\xb9\x88\xe6\x98\xaf PodSecurityPolicy\xef\xbc\x9f

<!--
[PodSecurityPolicy](/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-policy/) is
a built-in [admission controller](/blog/2019/03/21/a-guide-to-kubernetes-admission-controllers/)
that allows a cluster administrator to control security-sensitive aspects of the Pod specification.
-->
[PodSecurityPolicy](/zh-cn/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-policy/)
\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe5\x86\x85\xe7\xbd\xae\xe7\x9a\x84[\xe5\x87\x86\xe5\x85\xa5\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x88\xb6\xe5\x99\xa8](/blog/2019/03/21/a-guide-to-kubernetes-admission-controllers/)\xef\xbc\x8c
\xe5\x85\x81\xe8\xae\xb8\xe9\x9b\x86\xe7\xbe\xa4\xe7\xae\xa1\xe7\x90\x86\xe5\x91\x98\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x88\xb6 Pod \xe8\xa7\x84\xe7\xba\xa6\xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\xb6\x89\xe5\x8f\x8a\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x95\x8f\xe6\x84\x9f\xe5\x86\x85\xe5\xae\xb9\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
First, one or more PodSecurityPolicy resources are created in a cluster to define the requirements Pods must meet.
Then, RBAC rules are created to control which PodSecurityPolicy applies to a given pod.
If a pod meets the requirements of its PSP, it will be admitted to the cluster as usual.
In some cases, PSP can also modify Pod fields, effectively creating new defaults for those fields.
If a Pod does not meet the PSP requirements, it is rejected, and cannot run.
-->
\xe9\xa6\x96\xe5\x85\x88\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe9\x9b\x86\xe7\xbe\xa4\xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\x88\x9b\xe5\xbb\xba\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe6\x88\x96\xe5\xa4\x9a\xe4\xb8\xaa PodSecurityPolicy \xe8\xb5\x84\xe6\xba\x90\xe6\x9d\xa5\xe5\xae\x9a\xe4\xb9\x89 Pod \xe5\xbf\x85\xe9\xa1\xbb\xe6\xbb\xa1\xe8\xb6\xb3\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xa6\x81\xe6\xb1\x82\xe3\x80\x82
\xe7\x84\xb6\xe5\x90\x8e\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x88\x9b\xe5\xbb\xba RBAC \xe8\xa7\x84\xe5\x88\x99\xe6\x9d\xa5\xe5\x86\xb3\xe5\xae\x9a\xe4\xb8\xba\xe7\x89\xb9\xe5\xae\x9a\xe7\x9a\x84 Pod \xe5\xba\x94\xe7\x94\xa8\xe5\x93\xaa\xe4\xb8\xaa PodSecurityPolicy\xe3\x80\x82
\xe5\xa6\x82\xe6\x9e\x9c Pod \xe6\xbb\xa1\xe8\xb6\xb3\xe5\x85\xb6 PSP \xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xa6\x81\xe6\xb1\x82\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x88\x99\xe7\x85\xa7\xe5\xb8\xb8\xe8\xa2\xab\xe5\x85\x81\xe8\xae\xb8\xe8\xbf\x9b\xe5\x85\xa5\xe9\x9b\x86\xe7\xbe\xa4\xe3\x80\x82
\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe6\x9f\x90\xe4\xba\x9b\xe6\x83\x85\xe5\x86\xb5\xe4\xb8\x8b\xef\xbc\x8cPSP \xe8\xbf\x98\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe4\xbf\xae\xe6\x94\xb9 Pod \xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\x9c\x89\xe6\x95\x88\xe5\x9c\xb0\xe4\xb8\xba\xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xba\x9b\xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe5\x88\x9b\xe5\xbb\xba\xe6\x96\xb0\xe7\x9a\x84\xe9\xbb\x98\xe8\xae\xa4\xe5\x80\xbc\xe3\x80\x82
\xe5\xa6\x82\xe6\x9e\x9c Pod \xe4\xb8\x8d\xe7\xac\xa6\xe5\x90\x88 PSP \xe8\xa6\x81\xe6\xb1\x82\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x88\x99\xe8\xa2\xab\xe6\x8b\x92\xe7\xbb\x9d\xe8\xbf\x9b\xe5\x85\xa5\xe9\x9b\x86\xe7\xbe\xa4\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\xb9\xb6\xe4\xb8\x94\xe6\x97\xa0\xe6\xb3\x95\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
One more important thing to know about PodSecurityPolicy: it\xe2\x80\x99s not the same as
[PodSecurityContext](/docs/reference/kubernetes-api/workload-resources/pod-v1/#security-context).
-->
\xe5\x85\xb3\xe4\xba\x8e PodSecurityPolicy\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\xbf\x98\xe9\x9c\x80\xe8\xa6\x81\xe4\xba\x86\xe8\xa7\xa3\xef\xbc\x9a\xe5\xae\x83\xe4\xb8\x8e
[PodSecurityContext](/zh-cn/docs/reference/kubernetes-api/workload-resources/pod-v1/#security-context) \xe4\xb8\x8d\xe5\x90\x8c\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
A part of the Pod specification, PodSecurityContext (and its per-container counterpart `SecurityContext`)
is the collection of fields that specify many of the security-relevant settings for a Pod.
The security context dictates to the kubelet and container runtime how the Pod should actually be run.
In contrast, the PodSecurityPolicy only constrains (or defaults) the values that may be set on the security context.
-->
\xe4\xbd\x9c\xe4\xb8\xba Pod \xe8\xa7\x84\xe7\xba\xa6\xe7\x9a\x84\xe4\xb8\x80\xe9\x83\xa8\xe5\x88\x86\xef\xbc\x8cPodSecurityContext\xef\xbc\x88\xe5\x8f\x8a\xe5\x85\xb6\xe6\xaf\x8f\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe5\xaf\xb9\xe5\xba\x94\xe7\x9a\x84 `SecurityContext`\xef\xbc\x89
\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xb8\x80\xe7\xbb\x84\xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe7\x9a\x84\xe9\x9b\x86\xe5\x90\x88\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xba\x9b\xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe4\xb8\xba Pod \xe6\x8c\x87\xe5\xae\x9a\xe4\xba\x86\xe4\xb8\x8e\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe7\x9b\xb8\xe5\x85\xb3\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xae\xb8\xe5\xa4\x9a\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe3\x80\x82
\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe6\x96\x87\xe6\x8c\x87\xe7\xa4\xba kubelet \xe5\x92\x8c\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe6\x97\xb6\xe7\xa9\xb6\xe7\xab\x9f\xe5\xba\x94\xe8\xaf\xa5\xe5\xa6\x82\xe4\xbd\x95\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c Pod\xe3\x80\x82
\xe7\x9b\xb8\xe5\x8f\x8d\xef\xbc\x8cPodSecurityPolicy \xe4\xbb\x85\xe7\xba\xa6\xe6\x9d\x9f\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe8\x83\xbd\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe6\x96\x87\xe4\xb8\xad\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x80\xbc\xef\xbc\x88\xe6\x88\x96\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe9\xbb\x98\xe8\xae\xa4\xe5\x80\xbc\xef\xbc\x89\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
The deprecation of PSP does not affect PodSecurityContext in any way.
-->
\xe5\xbc\x83\xe7\x94\xa8 PSP \xe4\xb8\x8d\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe4\xbb\xbb\xe4\xbd\x95\xe6\x96\xb9\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe5\xbd\xb1\xe5\x93\x8d PodSecurityContext\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
## Why did we need PodSecurityPolicy?
-->
## \xe4\xbb\xa5\xe5\x89\x8d\xe4\xb8\xba\xe4\xbb\x80\xe4\xb9\x88\xe9\x9c\x80\xe8\xa6\x81 PodSecurityPolicy\xef\xbc\x9f

<!--
In Kubernetes, we define resources such as Deployments, StatefulSets, and Services that
represent the building blocks of software applications. The various controllers inside
a Kubernetes cluster react to these resources, creating further Kubernetes resources or
configuring some software or hardware to accomplish our goals.
-->
\xe5\x9c\xa8 Kubernetes \xe4\xb8\xad\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\x88\x91\xe4\xbb\xac\xe5\xae\x9a\xe4\xb9\x89\xe4\xba\x86 Deployment\xe3\x80\x81StatefulSet \xe5\x92\x8c Service \xe7\xad\x89\xe8\xb5\x84\xe6\xba\x90\xe3\x80\x82
\xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xba\x9b\xe8\xb5\x84\xe6\xba\x90\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe8\xa1\xa8\xe8\xbd\xaf\xe4\xbb\xb6\xe5\xba\x94\xe7\x94\xa8\xe7\xa8\x8b\xe5\xba\x8f\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x9e\x84\xe5\xbb\xba\xe5\x9d\x97\xe3\x80\x82Kubernetes \xe9\x9b\x86\xe7\xbe\xa4\xe4\xb8\xad\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x90\x84\xe7\xa7\x8d\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x88\xb6\xe5\x99\xa8\xe6\xa0\xb9\xe6\x8d\xae\xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xba\x9b\xe8\xb5\x84\xe6\xba\x90\xe5\x81\x9a\xe5\x87\xba\xe5\x8f\x8d\xe5\xba\x94\xef\xbc\x8c
\xe5\x88\x9b\xe5\xbb\xba\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe5\xa4\x9a\xe7\x9a\x84 Kubernetes \xe8\xb5\x84\xe6\xba\x90\xe6\x88\x96\xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xba\x9b\xe8\xbd\xaf\xe4\xbb\xb6\xe6\x88\x96\xe7\xa1\xac\xe4\xbb\xb6\xe6\x9d\xa5\xe5\xae\x9e\xe7\x8e\xb0\xe6\x88\x91\xe4\xbb\xac\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\x9b\xae\xe6\xa0\x87\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
In most Kubernetes clusters, 
RBAC (Role-Based Access Control) [rules](/docs/reference/access-authn-authz/rbac/#role-and-clusterrole)
control access to these resources. `list`, `get`, `create`, `edit`, and `delete` are
the sorts of API operations that RBAC cares about, 
but _RBAC does not consider what settings are being put into the resources it controls_.
For example, a Pod can be almost anything from a simple webserver to
a privileged command prompt offering full access to the underlying server node and all the data.
It\xe2\x80\x99s all the same to RBAC: a Pod is a Pod is a Pod.
-->
\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe5\xa4\xa7\xe5\xa4\x9a\xe6\x95\xb0 Kubernetes \xe9\x9b\x86\xe7\xbe\xa4\xe4\xb8\xad\xef\xbc\x8c\xe7\x94\xb1 RBAC\xef\xbc\x88\xe5\x9f\xba\xe4\xba\x8e\xe8\xa7\x92\xe8\x89\xb2\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xae\xbf\xe9\x97\xae\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x88\xb6\xef\xbc\x89[\xe8\xa7\x84\xe5\x88\x99](/zh-cn/docs/reference/access-authn-authz/rbac/#role-and-clusterrole)
\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x88\xb6\xe5\xaf\xb9\xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xba\x9b\xe8\xb5\x84\xe6\xba\x90\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xae\xbf\xe9\x97\xae\xe3\x80\x82 `list`\xe3\x80\x81`get`\xe3\x80\x81`create`\xe3\x80\x81`edit` \xe5\x92\x8c `delete` \xe6\x98\xaf RBAC \xe5\x85\xb3\xe5\xbf\x83\xe7\x9a\x84 API \xe6\x93\x8d\xe4\xbd\x9c\xe7\xb1\xbb\xe5\x9e\x8b\xef\xbc\x8c
\xe4\xbd\x86 **RBAC \xe4\xb8\x8d\xe8\x80\x83\xe8\x99\x91\xe5\x85\xb6\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x88\xb6\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xb5\x84\xe6\xba\x90\xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\x8a\xa0\xe5\x85\xa5\xe4\xba\x86\xe5\x93\xaa\xe4\xba\x9b\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae**\xe3\x80\x82\xe4\xbe\x8b\xe5\xa6\x82\xef\xbc\x8c
Pod \xe5\x87\xa0\xe4\xb9\x8e\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xbb\xbb\xe4\xbd\x95\xe4\xb8\x9c\xe8\xa5\xbf\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbe\x8b\xe5\xa6\x82\xe7\xae\x80\xe5\x8d\x95\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\xbd\x91\xe7\xbb\x9c\xe6\x9c\x8d\xe5\x8a\xa1\xe5\x99\xa8\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\x88\x96\xe8\x80\x85\xe6\x98\xaf\xe7\x89\xb9\xe6\x9d\x83\xe5\x91\xbd\xe4\xbb\xa4\xe6\x8f\x90\xe7\xa4\xba\xef\xbc\x88\xe6\x8f\x90\xe4\xbe\x9b\xe5\xaf\xb9\xe5\xba\x95\xe5\xb1\x82\xe6\x9c\x8d\xe5\x8a\xa1\xe5\x99\xa8\xe8\x8a\x82\xe7\x82\xb9\xe5\x92\x8c\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe6\x95\xb0\xe6\x8d\xae\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xae\x8c\xe5\x85\xa8\xe8\xae\xbf\xe9\x97\xae\xe6\x9d\x83\xe9\x99\x90\xef\xbc\x89\xe3\x80\x82
\xe8\xbf\x99\xe5\xaf\xb9 RBAC \xe6\x9d\xa5\xe8\xaf\xb4\xe9\x83\xbd\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xb8\x80\xe6\xa0\xb7\xe7\x9a\x84\xef\xbc\x9aPod \xe5\xb0\xb1\xe6\x98\xaf Pod \xe8\x80\x8c\xe5\xb7\xb2\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
To control what sorts of settings are allowed in the resources defined in your cluster,
you need Admission Control in addition to RBAC. Since Kubernetes 1.3,
PodSecurityPolicy has been the built-in way to do that for security-related Pod fields.
Using PodSecurityPolicy, you can prevent \xe2\x80\x9ccreate Pod\xe2\x80\x9d from automatically meaning \xe2\x80\x9croot on every cluster node,\xe2\x80\x9d
without needing to deploy additional external admission controllers.
-->
\xe8\xa6\x81\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x88\xb6\xe9\x9b\x86\xe7\xbe\xa4\xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\xae\x9a\xe4\xb9\x89\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xb5\x84\xe6\xba\x90\xe5\x85\x81\xe8\xae\xb8\xe5\x93\xaa\xe4\xba\x9b\xe7\xb1\xbb\xe5\x9e\x8b\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xef\xbc\x8c\xe9\x99\xa4\xe4\xba\x86 RBAC \xe4\xb9\x8b\xe5\xa4\x96\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\xbf\x98\xe9\x9c\x80\xe8\xa6\x81\xe5\x87\x86\xe5\x85\xa5\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x88\xb6\xe3\x80\x82
\xe4\xbb\x8e Kubernetes 1.3 \xe5\xbc\x80\xe5\xa7\x8b\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x86\x85\xe7\xbd\xae PodSecurityPolicy \xe4\xb8\x80\xe7\x9b\xb4\xe8\xa2\xab\xe4\xbd\x9c\xe4\xb8\xba Pod \xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe7\x9b\xb8\xe5\x85\xb3\xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x87\x86\xe5\x85\xa5\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x88\xb6\xe6\x9c\xba\xe5\x88\xb6\xe3\x80\x82
\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8 PodSecurityPolicy\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe9\x98\xb2\xe6\xad\xa2\xe2\x80\x9c\xe5\x88\x9b\xe5\xbb\xba Pod\xe2\x80\x9d\xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe8\x83\xbd\xe5\x8a\x9b\xe8\x87\xaa\xe5\x8a\xa8\xe5\x8f\x98\xe6\x88\x90\xe2\x80\x9c\xe6\xaf\x8f\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe9\x9b\x86\xe7\xbe\xa4\xe8\x8a\x82\xe7\x82\xb9\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe7\x9a\x84 root \xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\x88\xb7\xe2\x80\x9d\xef\xbc\x8c
\xe5\xb9\xb6\xe4\xb8\x94\xe6\x97\xa0\xe9\x9c\x80\xe9\x83\xa8\xe7\xbd\xb2\xe9\xa2\x9d\xe5\xa4\x96\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xa4\x96\xe9\x83\xa8\xe5\x87\x86\xe5\x85\xa5\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x88\xb6\xe5\x99\xa8\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
## Why is PodSecurityPolicy going away?
-->
## \xe7\x8e\xb0\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe4\xb8\xba\xe4\xbb\x80\xe4\xb9\x88 PodSecurityPolicy \xe8\xa6\x81\xe6\xb6\x88\xe5\xa4\xb1\xef\xbc\x9f

<!--
In the years since PodSecurityPolicy was first introduced, we have realized that
PSP has some serious usability problems that can\xe2\x80\x99t be addressed without making breaking changes.
-->
\xe8\x87\xaa\xe4\xbb\x8e\xe9\xa6\x96\xe6\xac\xa1\xe5\xbc\x95\xe5\x85\xa5 PodSecurityPolicy \xe4\xbb\xa5\xe6\x9d\xa5\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\x88\x91\xe4\xbb\xac\xe5\xb7\xb2\xe7\xbb\x8f\xe6\x84\x8f\xe8\xaf\x86\xe5\x88\xb0 PSP \xe5\xad\x98\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xba\x9b\xe4\xb8\xa5\xe9\x87\x8d\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\x80\xa7\xe9\x97\xae\xe9\xa2\x98\xef\xbc\x8c
\xe5\x8f\xaa\xe6\x9c\x89\xe5\x81\x9a\xe5\x87\xba\xe6\x96\xad\xe8\xa3\x82\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x94\xb9\xe5\x8f\x98\xe6\x89\x8d\xe8\x83\xbd\xe8\xa7\xa3\xe5\x86\xb3\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
The way PSPs are applied to Pods has proven confusing to nearly everyone that has attempted to use them.
It is easy to accidentally grant broader permissions than intended,
and difficult to inspect which PSP(s) apply in a given situation. The \xe2\x80\x9cchanging Pod defaults\xe2\x80\x9d feature can be handy,
but is only supported for certain Pod settings and it\xe2\x80\x99s not obvious when they will or will not apply to your Pod.
Without a \xe2\x80\x9cdry run\xe2\x80\x9d or audit mode, it\xe2\x80\x99s impractical to retrofit PSP to existing clusters safely,
and it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible for PSP to ever be enabled by default.
-->
\xe5\xae\x9e\xe8\xb7\xb5\xe8\xaf\x81\xe6\x98\x8e\xef\xbc\x8cPSP \xe5\xba\x94\xe7\x94\xa8\xe4\xba\x8e Pod \xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x96\xb9\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe8\xae\xa9\xe5\x87\xa0\xe4\xb9\x8e\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe5\xb0\x9d\xe8\xaf\x95\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe5\xae\x83\xe4\xbb\xac\xe7\x9a\x84\xe4\xba\xba\xe9\x83\xbd\xe6\x84\x9f\xe5\x88\xb0\xe5\x9b\xb0\xe6\x83\x91\xe3\x80\x82
\xe5\xbe\x88\xe5\xae\xb9\xe6\x98\x93\xe6\x84\x8f\xe5\xa4\x96\xe6\x8e\x88\xe4\xba\x88\xe6\xaf\x94\xe9\xa2\x84\xe6\x9c\x9f\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe5\xb9\xbf\xe6\xb3\x9b\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x9d\x83\xe9\x99\x90\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\xb9\xb6\xe4\xb8\x94\xe9\x9a\xbe\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe6\x9f\xa5\xe7\x9c\x8b\xe6\x9f\x90\xe7\xa7\x8d\xe7\x89\xb9\xe5\xae\x9a\xe6\x83\x85\xe5\x86\xb5\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe5\xba\x94\xe7\x94\xa8\xe4\xba\x86\xe5\x93\xaa\xe4\xba\x9b PSP\xe3\x80\x82
\xe2\x80\x9c\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe6\x94\xb9 Pod \xe9\xbb\x98\xe8\xae\xa4\xe5\x80\xbc\xe2\x80\x9d\xe5\x8a\x9f\xe8\x83\xbd\xe5\xbe\x88\xe6\x96\xb9\xe4\xbe\xbf\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbd\x86\xe4\xbb\x85\xe6\x94\xaf\xe6\x8c\x81\xe6\x9f\x90\xe4\xba\x9b Pod \xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\x80\x8c\xe4\xb8\x94\xe6\x97\xa0\xe6\xb3\x95\xe6\x98\x8e\xe7\xa1\xae\xe7\x9f\xa5\xe9\x81\x93\xe5\xae\x83\xe4\xbb\xac\xe4\xbd\x95\xe6\x97\xb6\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe6\x88\x96\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe5\xba\x94\xe7\x94\xa8\xe4\xba\x8e\xe7\x9a\x84 Pod\xe3\x80\x82
\xe5\xa6\x82\xe6\x9e\x9c\xe6\xb2\xa1\xe6\x9c\x89\xe2\x80\x9c\xe8\xaf\x95\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe2\x80\x9d\xe6\x88\x96\xe5\xae\xa1\xe8\xae\xa1\xe6\xa8\xa1\xe5\xbc\x8f\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\xb0\x86 PSP \xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe5\x9c\xb0\xe6\x94\xb9\xe9\x80\xa0\xe5\xb9\xb6\xe5\xba\x94\xe7\x94\xa8\xe5\x88\xb0\xe7\x8e\xb0\xe6\x9c\x89\xe9\x9b\x86\xe7\xbe\xa4\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe5\x88\x87\xe5\xae\x9e\xe9\x99\x85\xe7\x9a\x84\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\xb9\xb6\xe4\xb8\x94\xe6\xb0\xb8\xe8\xbf\x9c\xe9\x83\xbd\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe8\x83\xbd\xe9\xbb\x98\xe8\xae\xa4\xe5\x90\xaf\xe7\x94\xa8 PSP\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
Today, you\xe2\x80\x99re not limited only to deploying PSP or writing your own custom admission controller.
Several external admission controllers are available that incorporate lessons learned from PSP to

[Kyverno](https://github.com/kyverno/kyverno/), and
[OPA/Gatekeeper](https://github.com/open-policy-agent/gatekeeper/) are all well-known, and each has its fans.
-->
\xe5\xa6\x82\xe4\xbb\x8a\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe5\x86\x8d\xe5\xb1\x80\xe9\x99\x90\xe4\xba\x8e\xe9\x83\xa8\xe7\xbd\xb2 PSP \xe6\x88\x96\xe7\xbc\x96\xe5\x86\x99\xe8\x87\xaa\xe5\xb7\xb1\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\x87\xaa\xe5\xae\x9a\xe4\xb9\x89\xe5\x87\x86\xe5\x85\xa5\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x88\xb6\xe5\x99\xa8\xe3\x80\x82

## \xe4\xb8\x8b\xe4\xb8\x80\xe6\xad\xa5\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xbb\x80\xe4\xb9\x88\xef\xbc\x9f

<!--
Kubernetes SIG Security, SIG Auth, and a diverse collection of other community members
have been working together for months to ensure that what\xe2\x80\x99s coming next is going to be awesome.
We have developed a Kubernetes Enhancement Proposal ([KEP 2579](https://github.com/kubernetes/enhancements/issues/2579))
and a prototype for a new feature, currently being called by the temporary name "PSP Replacement Policy."
We are targeting an Alpha release in Kubernetes 1.22.
-->
Kubernetes SIG Security\xe3\x80\x81SIG Auth \xe5\x92\x8c\xe5\x85\xb6\xe4\xbb\x96\xe7\xa4\xbe\xe5\x8c\xba\xe6\x88\x90\xe5\x91\x98\xe5\x87\xa0\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe6\x9c\x88\xe6\x9d\xa5\xe4\xb8\x80\xe7\x9b\xb4\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe5\x80\xbe\xe5\x8a\x9b\xe5\x90\x88\xe4\xbd\x9c\xef\xbc\x8c\xe7\xa1\xae\xe4\xbf\x9d\xe6\x8e\xa5\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe6\x9d\xa5\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x96\xb9\xe6\xa1\x88\xe8\x83\xbd\xe4\xbb\xa4\xe4\xba\xba\xe6\x83\x8a\xe5\x8f\xb9\xe3\x80\x82
\xe6\x88\x91\xe4\xbb\xac\xe6\x8b\x9f\xe5\xae\x9a\xe4\xba\x86 Kubernetes \xe5\xa2\x9e\xe5\xbc\xba\xe6\x8f\x90\xe6\xa1\x88\xef\xbc\x88[KEP 2579](https://github.com/kubernetes/enhancements/issues/2579)\xef\xbc\x89
\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe5\x8f\x8a\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe6\x96\xb0\xe5\x8a\x9f\xe8\x83\xbd\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x8e\x9f\xe5\x9e\x8b\xef\xbc\x8c\xe7\x9b\xae\xe5\x89\x8d\xe7\xa7\xb0\xe4\xb9\x8b\xe4\xb8\xba\xe2\x80\x9cPSP \xe6\x9b\xbf\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5\xe2\x80\x9d\xe3\x80\x82
\xe6\x88\x91\xe4\xbb\xac\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\x9b\xae\xe6\xa0\x87\xe6\x98\xaf\xe5\x9c\xa8 Kubernetes 1.22 \xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\x8f\x91\xe5\xb8\x83 Alpha \xe7\x89\x88\xe6\x9c\xac\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
PSP Replacement Policy starts with the realization that
since there is a robust ecosystem of external admission controllers already available,
PSP\xe2\x80\x99s replacement doesn\xe2\x80\x99t need to be all things to all people.
Simplicity of deployment and adoption is the key advantage a built-in admission controller has
compared to an external webhook, so we have focused on how to best utilize that advantage.
-->
PSP \xe6\x9b\xbf\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5\xe5\xa7\x8b\xe4\xba\x8e\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\x88\x91\xe4\xbb\xac\xe8\xae\xa4\xe8\xaf\x86\xe5\x88\xb0\xe5\xb7\xb2\xe7\xbb\x8f\xe6\x9c\x89\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe5\xbc\xba\xe5\xa4\xa7\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xa4\x96\xe9\x83\xa8\xe5\x87\x86\xe5\x85\xa5\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x88\xb6\xe5\x99\xa8\xe7\x94\x9f\xe6\x80\x81\xe7\xb3\xbb\xe7\xbb\x9f\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe7\x94\xa8\xef\xbc\x8c
\xe6\x89\x80\xe4\xbb\xa5\xef\xbc\x8cPSP \xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x9b\xbf\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe5\x93\x81\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe9\x9c\x80\xe8\xa6\x81\xe6\xbb\xa1\xe8\xb6\xb3\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe4\xba\xba\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe9\x9c\x80\xe6\xb1\x82\xe3\x80\x82\xe4\xb8\x8e\xe5\xa4\x96\xe9\x83\xa8 Webhook \xe7\x9b\xb8\xe6\xaf\x94\xef\xbc\x8c
\xe9\x83\xa8\xe7\xbd\xb2\xe5\x92\x8c\xe9\x87\x87\xe7\x94\xa8\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\xae\x80\xe5\x8d\x95\xe6\x80\xa7\xe6\x98\xaf\xe5\x86\x85\xe7\xbd\xae\xe5\x87\x86\xe5\x85\xa5\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x88\xb6\xe5\x99\xa8\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x85\xb3\xe9\x94\xae\xe4\xbc\x98\xe5\x8a\xbf\xe3\x80\x82\xe6\x88\x91\xe4\xbb\xac\xe4\xb8\x93\xe6\xb3\xa8\xe4\xba\x8e\xe5\xa6\x82\xe4\xbd\x95\xe6\x9c\x80\xe5\xa5\xbd\xe5\x9c\xb0\xe5\x88\xa9\xe7\x94\xa8\xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xbc\x98\xe5\x8a\xbf\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
PSP Replacement Policy is designed to be as simple as practically possible
while providing enough flexibility to really be useful in production at scale.
It has soft rollout features to enable retrofitting it to existing clusters,
and is configurable enough that it can eventually be active by default.
It can be deactivated partially or entirely, to coexist with external admission controllers for advanced use cases.
-->
PSP \xe6\x9b\xbf\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5\xe6\x97\xa8\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe5\xb0\xbd\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe8\x83\xbd\xe7\xae\x80\xe5\x8d\x95\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x90\x8c\xe6\x97\xb6\xe6\x8f\x90\xe4\xbe\x9b\xe8\xb6\xb3\xe5\xa4\x9f\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\x81\xb5\xe6\xb4\xbb\xe6\x80\xa7\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe6\x94\xaf\xe6\x92\x91\xe5\xa4\xa7\xe8\xa7\x84\xe6\xa8\xa1\xe7\x94\x9f\xe4\xba\xa7\xe5\x9c\xba\xe6\x99\xaf\xe3\x80\x82
\xe5\xae\x83\xe5\x85\xb7\xe6\x9c\x89\xe6\x9f\x94\xe6\x80\xa7\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe7\xba\xbf\xe8\x83\xbd\xe5\x8a\x9b\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe4\xbe\xbf\xe4\xba\x8e\xe5\xb0\x86\xe5\x85\xb6\xe6\x94\xb9\xe8\xa3\x85\xe5\x88\xb0\xe7\x8e\xb0\xe6\x9c\x89\xe9\x9b\x86\xe7\xbe\xa4\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\xb9\xb6\xe4\xb8\x94\xe6\x96\xb0\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5\xe6\x98\xaf\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae\xe7\x9a\x84\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe4\xb8\xba\xe9\xbb\x98\xe8\xae\xa4\xe5\x90\xaf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe3\x80\x82
PSP \xe6\x9b\xbf\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe8\xa2\xab\xe9\x83\xa8\xe5\x88\x86\xe6\x88\x96\xe5\x85\xa8\xe9\x83\xa8\xe7\xa6\x81\xe7\x94\xa8\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe4\xbe\xbf\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe9\xab\x98\xe7\xba\xa7\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe5\x9c\xba\xe6\x99\xaf\xe4\xb8\xad\xe4\xb8\x8e\xe5\xa4\x96\xe9\x83\xa8\xe5\x87\x86\xe5\x85\xa5\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x88\xb6\xe5\x99\xa8\xe5\x85\xb1\xe5\xad\x98\xe3\x80\x82

\xe8\xaf\xb7\xe6\x9f\xa5\xe7\x9c\x8b PSP \xe6\x9b\xbf\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5 KEP \xe5\xb9\xb6\xe8\x80\x83\xe8\x99\x91\xe5\xae\x83\xe6\x98\xaf\xe5\x90\xa6\xe9\x80\x82\xe5\x90\x88\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe7\x9a\x84\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe5\x9c\xba\xe6\x99\xaf\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
If you\xe2\x80\x99re making extensive use of the flexibility of PSP with numerous PSPs and complex binding rules,
you will likely find the simplicity of PSP Replacement Policy too limiting.
Use the next year to evaluate the other admission controller choices in the ecosystem.
There are resources available to ease this transition,
such as the [Gatekeeper Policy Library](https://github.com/open-policy-agent/gatekeeper-library).
-->

<!--
If you\xe2\x80\x99re just beginning your PSP journey, you will save time and effort by keeping it simple.
You can approximate the functionality of PSP Replacement Policy today by using the Pod Security Standards\xe2\x80\x99 PSPs.
If you set the cluster default by binding a Baseline or Restricted policy to the `system:serviceaccounts` group,
and then make a more-permissive policy available as needed in certain
Namespaces [using ServiceAccount bindings](/docs/concepts/policy/pod-security-policy/#run-another-pod),
you will avoid many of the PSP pitfalls and have an easy migration to PSP Replacement Policy.
If your needs are much more complex than this, your effort is probably better spent adopting
one of the more fully-featured external admission controllers mentioned above.
-->

Namespaces that lack any configuration at all should be considered significant gaps in your cluster

<!--
### Embrace the principle of least privilege

In an ideal world, every pod in every namespace would meet the requirements of the `restricted`
policy. However, this is not possible nor practical, as some workloads will require elevated
privileges for legitimate reasons.
-->
### \xe6\x8b\xa5\xe6\x8a\xb1\xe6\x9c\x80\xe5\xb0\x8f\xe7\x89\xb9\xe6\x9d\x83\xe5\x8e\x9f\xe5\x88\x99

\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe8\xbf\x87\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\xbf\x99\xe6\x97\xa2\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe8\x83\xbd\xe4\xb9\x9f\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe7\x8e\xb0\xe5\xae\x9e\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\x9f\x90\xe4\xba\x9b\xe8\xb4\x9f\xe8\xbd\xbd\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe5\x9b\xa0\xe4\xb8\xba\xe5\x90\x88\xe7\x90\x86\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x8e\x9f\xe5\x9b\xa0\xe8\x80\x8c\xe9\x9c\x80\xe8\xa6\x81\xe7\x89\xb9\xe6\x9d\x83\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x8f\x90\xe5\x8d\x87\xe3\x80\x82

- Namespaces allowing `privileged` workloads should establish and enforce appropriate access controls.
- For workloads running in those permissive namespaces, maintain documentation about their unique
  security requirements. If at all possible, consider how those requirements could be further
  constrained.
-->
- \xe5\x85\x81\xe8\xae\xb8 `privileged` \xe8\xb4\x9f\xe8\xbd\xbd\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x90\x8d\xe5\xad\x97\xe7\xa9\xba\xe9\x97\xb4\xe9\x9c\x80\xe8\xa6\x81\xe5\xbb\xba\xe7\xab\x8b\xe5\xb9\xb6\xe5\xae\x9e\xe6\x96\xbd\xe9\x80\x82\xe5\xbd\x93\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xae\xbf\xe9\x97\xae\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x88\xb6\xe6\x9c\xba\xe5\x88\xb6\xe3\x80\x82
- \xe5\xaf\xb9\xe4\xba\x8e\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe7\x89\xb9\xe6\x9d\x83\xe5\xae\xbd\xe6\x9d\xbe\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x90\x8d\xe5\xad\x97\xe7\xa9\xba\xe9\x97\xb4\xe4\xb8\xad\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xb4\x9f\xe8\xbd\xbd\xef\xbc\x8c\xe9\x9c\x80\xe8\xa6\x81\xe7\xbb\xb4\xe6\x8a\xa4\xe5\x85\xb6\xe7\x8b\xac\xe7\x89\xb9\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe6\x80\xa7\xe9\x9c\x80\xe6\xb1\x82\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x96\x87\xe6\xa1\xa3\xe3\x80\x82
  \xe5\xa6\x82\xe6\x9e\x9c\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe8\x83\xbd\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xaf\x9d\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\xa6\x81\xe8\x80\x83\xe8\x99\x91\xe5\xa6\x82\xe4\xbd\x95\xe8\xbf\x9b\xe4\xb8\x80\xe6\xad\xa5\xe7\xba\xa6\xe6\x9d\x9f\xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xba\x9b\xe9\x9c\x80\xe6\xb1\x82\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
### Adopt a multi-mode strategy

The `audit` and `warn` modes of the Pod Security Standards admission controller make it easy to
collect important security insights about your pods without breaking existing workloads.
-->
### \xe9\x87\x87\xe7\x94\xa8\xe5\xa4\x9a\xe7\xa7\x8d\xe6\xa8\xa1\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5

Pod \xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe6\x80\xa7\xe6\xa0\x87\xe5\x87\x86\xe5\x87\x86\xe5\x85\xa5\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x88\xb6\xe5\x99\xa8\xe7\x9a\x84 `audit` \xe5\x92\x8c `warn` \xe6\xa8\xa1\xe5\xbc\x8f\xef\xbc\x88mode\xef\xbc\x89
\xe8\x83\xbd\xe5\xa4\x9f\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe5\xbd\xb1\xe5\x93\x8d\xe7\x8e\xb0\xe6\x9c\x89\xe8\xb4\x9f\xe8\xbd\xbd\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x89\x8d\xe6\x8f\x90\xe4\xb8\x8b\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\xae\xa9\xe8\xaf\xa5\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x88\xb6\xe5\x99\xa8\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe6\x96\xb9\xe4\xbe\xbf\xe5\x9c\xb0\xe6\x94\xb6\xe9\x9b\x86\xe5\x85\xb3\xe4\xba\x8e Pod \xe7\x9a\x84\xe9\x87\x8d\xe8\xa6\x81\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe4\xbf\xa1\xe6\x81\xaf\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
It is good practice to enable these modes for all namespaces, setting them to the _desired_ level
and version you would eventually like to `enforce`. The warnings and audit annotations generated in
this phase can guide you toward that state. If you expect workload authors to make changes to fit
within the desired level, enable the `warn` mode. If you expect to use audit logs to monitor/drive
changes to fit within the desired level, enable the `audit` mode.
-->
\xe9\x92\x88\xe5\xaf\xb9\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe5\x90\x8d\xe5\xad\x97\xe7\xa9\xba\xe9\x97\xb4\xe5\x90\xaf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xba\x9b\xe6\xa8\xa1\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xb8\x80\xe7\xa7\x8d\xe5\xa5\xbd\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xae\x9e\xe8\xb7\xb5\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\xb0\x86\xe5\xae\x83\xe4\xbb\xac\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe4\xb8\xba\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe6\x9c\x80\xe7\xbb\x88\xe6\x89\x93\xe7\xae\x97 `enforce` \xe7\x9a\x84
 _\xe6\x9c\x9f\xe6\x9c\x9b\xe7\x9a\x84_ \xe7\xba\xa7\xe5\x88\xab\xe5\x92\x8c\xe7\x89\x88\xe6\x9c\xac\xe3\x80\x82\xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xb8\x80\xe9\x98\xb6\xe6\xae\xb5\xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\x89\x80\xe7\x94\x9f\xe6\x88\x90\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xad\xa6\xe5\x91\x8a\xe5\x92\x8c\xe5\xae\xa1\xe8\xae\xa1\xe6\xb3\xa8\xe8\xa7\xa3\xe4\xbf\xa1\xe6\x81\xaf\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe5\xb8\xae\xe5\x8a\xa9\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe5\x88\xb0\xe8\xbe\xbe\xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xb8\x80\xe7\x8a\xb6\xe6\x80\x81\xe3\x80\x82
\xe5\xa6\x82\xe6\x9e\x9c\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe6\x9c\x9f\xe6\x9c\x9b\xe8\xb4\x9f\xe8\xbd\xbd\xe7\x9a\x84\xe4\xbd\x9c\xe8\x80\x85\xe8\x83\xbd\xe5\xa4\x9f\xe4\xbd\x9c\xe5\x87\xba\xe5\x8f\x98\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe4\xbe\xbf\xe9\x80\x82\xe5\xba\x94\xe6\x9c\x9f\xe6\x9c\x9b\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\xba\xa7\xe5\x88\xab\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe5\x90\xaf\xe7\x94\xa8 `warn` \xe6\xa8\xa1\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe3\x80\x82
\xe5\xa6\x82\xe6\x9e\x9c\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe5\xb8\x8c\xe6\x9c\x9b\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe5\xae\xa1\xe8\xae\xa1\xe6\x97\xa5\xe5\xbf\x97\xe4\xba\x86\xe7\x9b\x91\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x92\x8c\xe9\xa9\xb1\xe5\x8a\xa8\xe5\x8f\x98\xe6\x9b\xb4\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe4\xbe\xbf\xe8\xb4\x9f\xe8\xbd\xbd\xe8\x83\xbd\xe5\xa4\x9f\xe9\x80\x82\xe5\xba\x94\xe6\x9c\x9f\xe6\x9c\x9b\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\xba\xa7\xe5\x88\xab\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe5\x90\xaf\xe7\x94\xa8 `audit` \xe6\xa8\xa1\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
When you have the `enforce` mode set to your desired value, these modes can still be useful in a
few different ways:

- By setting `warn` to the same level as `enforce`, clients will receive warnings when attempting
  to create Pods (or resources that have Pod templates) that do not pass validation. This will help
  them update those resources to become compliant.
- In Namespaces that pin `enforce` to a specific non-latest version, setting the `audit` and `warn`
  modes to the same level as `enforce`, but to the `latest` version, gives visibility into settings
  that were allowed by previous versions but are not allowed per current best practices.
-->
\xe5\xbd\x93\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe5\xb0\x86 `enforce` \xe6\xa8\xa1\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe4\xb8\xba\xe6\x9c\x9f\xe6\x9c\x9b\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x8f\x96\xe5\x80\xbc\xe6\x97\xb6\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xba\x9b\xe6\xa8\xa1\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe5\x90\x8c\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x9c\xba\xe5\x90\x88\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe4\xbb\x8d\xe7\x84\xb6\xe6\x98\xaf\xe6\x9c\x89\xe7\x94\xa8\xe7\x9a\x84\xef\xbc\x9a

- \xe9\x80\x9a\xe8\xbf\x87\xe5\xb0\x86 `warn` \xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe4\xb8\xba `enforce` \xe7\x9b\xb8\xe5\x90\x8c\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\xba\xa7\xe5\x88\xab\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\xae\xa2\xe6\x88\xb7\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe5\xb0\x9d\xe8\xaf\x95\xe5\x88\x9b\xe5\xbb\xba\xe6\x97\xa0\xe6\xb3\x95\xe9\x80\x9a\xe8\xbf\x87\xe5\x90\x88\xe6\xb3\x95\xe6\xa3\x80\xe6\x9f\xa5\xe7\x9a\x84 Pod
  \xef\xbc\x88\xe6\x88\x96\xe8\x80\x85\xe5\x8c\x85\xe5\x90\xab Pod \xe6\xa8\xa1\xe6\x9d\xbf\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xb5\x84\xe6\xba\x90\xef\xbc\x89\xe6\x97\xb6\xe6\x94\xb6\xe5\x88\xb0\xe8\xad\xa6\xe5\x91\x8a\xe4\xbf\xa1\xe6\x81\xaf\xe3\x80\x82\xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xba\x9b\xe4\xbf\xa1\xe6\x81\xaf\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe5\xb8\xae\xe5\x8a\xa9\xe4\xba\x8e\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe6\x96\xb0\xe8\xb5\x84\xe6\xba\x90\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe5\x85\xb6\xe5\x90\x88\xe8\xa7\x84\xe3\x80\x82
- \xe5\x9c\xa8\xe5\xb0\x86 `enforce` \xe9\x94\x81\xe5\xae\x9a\xe5\x88\xb0\xe7\x89\xb9\xe5\xae\x9a\xe7\x9a\x84\xe9\x9d\x9e\xe6\x9c\x80\xe6\x96\xb0\xe7\x89\x88\xe6\x9c\xac\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x90\x8d\xe5\xad\x97\xe7\xa9\xba\xe9\x97\xb4\xe4\xb8\xad\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\xb0\x86 `audit` \xe5\x92\x8c `warn`
  \xe6\xa8\xa1\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe4\xb8\xba `enforce` \xe4\xb8\x80\xe6\xa0\xb7\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\xba\xa7\xe5\x88\xab\xe8\x80\x8c\xe9\x9d\x9e `latest` \xe7\x89\x88\xe6\x9c\xac\xef\xbc\x8c
  \xe8\xbf\x99\xe6\xa0\xb7\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe6\x96\xb9\xe4\xbe\xbf\xe7\x9c\x8b\xe5\x88\xb0\xe4\xb9\x8b\xe5\x89\x8d\xe7\x89\x88\xe6\x9c\xac\xe6\x89\x80\xe5\x85\x81\xe8\xae\xb8\xe4\xbd\x86\xe5\xbd\x93\xe5\x89\x8d\xe6\x9c\x80\xe4\xbd\xb3\xe5\xae\x9e\xe8\xb7\xb5\xe4\xb8\xad\xe8\xa2\xab\xe7\xa6\x81\xe6\xad\xa2\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe3\x80\x82

b'---
reviewers:
- tallclair
- liggitt
title: Enforcing Pod Security Standards
weight: 40
---

<!-- overview -->

This page provides an overview of best practices when it comes to enforcing
[Pod Security Standards](/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-standards).

<!-- body -->

## Using the built-in Pod Security Admission Controller

{{< feature-state for_k8s_version="v1.25" state="stable" >}}

The [Pod Security Admission Controller](/docs/reference/access-authn-authz/admission-controllers/#podsecurity)
intends to replace the deprecated PodSecurityPolicies. 

### Configure all cluster namespaces

Namespaces that lack any configuration at all should be considered significant gaps in your cluster
security model. We recommend taking the time to analyze the types of workloads occurring in each
namespace, and by referencing the Pod Security Standards, decide on an appropriate level for
each of them. Unlabeled namespaces should only indicate that they've yet to be evaluated.

In the scenario that all workloads in all namespaces have the same security requirements,
we provide an [example](/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/enforce-standards-namespace-labels/#applying-to-all-namespaces)
that illustrates how the PodSecurity labels can be applied in bulk.

### Embrace the principle of least privilege

In an ideal world, every pod in every namespace would meet the requirements of the `restricted`
policy. However, this is not possible nor practical, as some workloads will require elevated
privileges for legitimate reasons.

- Namespaces allowing `privileged` workloads should establish and enforce appropriate access controls.
- For workloads running in those permissive namespaces, maintain documentation about their unique
  security requirements. If at all possible, consider how those requirements could be further
  constrained.

### Adopt a multi-mode strategy

The `audit` and `warn` modes of the Pod Security Standards admission controller make it easy to
collect important security insights about your pods without breaking existing workloads.

It is good practice to enable these modes for all namespaces, setting them to the _desired_ level
and version you would eventually like to `enforce`. The warnings and audit annotations generated in
this phase can guide you toward that state. If you expect workload authors to make changes to fit
within the desired level, enable the `warn` mode. If you expect to use audit logs to monitor/drive
changes to fit within the desired level, enable the `audit` mode.

When you have the `enforce` mode set to your desired value, these modes can still be useful in a
few different ways:

- By setting `warn` to the same level as `enforce`, clients will receive warnings when attempting
  to create Pods (or resources that have Pod templates) that do not pass validation. This will help
  them update those resources to become compliant.
- In Namespaces that pin `enforce` to a specific non-latest version, setting the `audit` and `warn`
  modes to the same level as `enforce`, but to the `latest` version, gives visibility into settings
  that were allowed by previous versions but are not allowed per current best practices.

## Third-party alternatives

{{% thirdparty-content %}}

Other alternatives for enforcing security profiles are being developed in the Kubernetes
ecosystem:

- [Kubewarden](https://github.com/kubewarden).
- [Kyverno](https://kyverno.io/policies/).
- [OPA Gatekeeper](https://github.com/open-policy-agent/gatekeeper).

The decision to go with a _built-in_ solution (e.g. PodSecurity admission controller) versus a
third-party tool is entirely dependent on your own situation. When evaluating any solution,
trust of your supply chain is crucial. Ultimately, using _any_ of the aforementioned approaches
will be better than doing nothing.'

## \xeb\x82\xb4\xec\x9e\xa5\xeb\x90\x9c \xed\x8c\x8c\xeb\x93\x9c \xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x81\x90\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x8b\xb0 \xec\x96\xb4\xeb\x93\x9c\xeb\xaf\xb8\xec\x85\x98 \xec\xbb\xa8\xed\x8a\xb8\xeb\xa1\xa4\xeb\x9f\xac \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9

{{< feature-state for_k8s_version="v1.23" state="beta" >}}

[\xed\x8c\x8c\xeb\x93\x9c \xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x81\x90\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x8b\xb0 \xec\x96\xb4\xeb\x93\x9c\xeb\xaf\xb8\xec\x85\x98 \xec\xbb\xa8\xed\x8a\xb8\xeb\xa1\xa4\xeb\x9f\xac(Pod Security Admission Controller)](/docs/reference/access-authn-authz/admission-controllers/#podsecurity)\xeb\x8a\x94
\xeb\x8d\x94 \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x83\x81 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xeb\x90\x98\xec\xa7\x80 \xec\x95\x8a\xeb\x8a\x94 \xed\x8c\x8c\xeb\x93\x9c\xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x81\x90\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x8b\xb0\xed\x8f\xb4\xeb\xa6\xac\xec\x8b\x9c(PodSecurityPolicy)\xeb\xa5\xbc \xeb\x8c\x80\xec\xb2\xb4\xed\x95\x9c\xeb\x8b\xa4. 

### \xeb\xaa\xa8\xeb\x93\xa0 \xed\x81\xb4\xeb\x9f\xac\xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x84\xb0 \xeb\x84\xa4\xec\x9e\x84\xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x8e\x98\xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x8a\xa4 \xea\xb5\xac\xec\x84\xb1

\xea\xb5\xac\xec\x84\xb1\xec\x9d\xb4 \xec\xa0\x84\xed\x98\x80 \xec\x97\x86\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\x84\xa4\xec\x9e\x84\xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x8e\x98\xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x8a\xa4\xeb\x8a\x94 \xed\x81\xb4\xeb\x9f\xac\xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x84\xb0 \xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x81\x90\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x8b\xb0 \xeb\xaa\xa8\xeb\x8d\xb8\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c \xec\x8b\xac\xea\xb0\x81\xed\x95\x9c \xed\x8b\x88\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c \xea\xb0\x84\xec\xa3\xbc\xed\x95\xb4\xec\x95\xbc
\xed\x95\x9c\xeb\x8b\xa4. \xec\x8b\x9c\xea\xb0\x84\xec\x9d\x84 \xeb\x93\xa4\xec\x97\xac \xea\xb0\x81 \xeb\x84\xa4\xec\x9e\x84\xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x8e\x98\xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x8a\xa4\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c \xeb\xb0\x9c\xec\x83\x9d\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\x9b\x8c\xed\x81\xac\xeb\xa1\x9c\xeb\x93\x9c \xec\x9c\xa0\xed\x98\x95\xec\x9d\x84 \xeb\xb6\x84\xec\x84\x9d\xed\x95\x98\xea\xb3\xa0, 
\xed\x8c\x8c\xeb\x93\x9c \xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x81\x90\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x8b\xb0 \xed\x8f\xb4\xeb\xa6\xac\xec\x8b\x9c\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\xb0\xb8\xec\xa1\xb0\xed\x95\x98\xec\x97\xac \xea\xb0\x81\xea\xb0\x81\xec\x97\x90 \xec\xa0\x81\xed\x95\xa9\xed\x95\x9c \xec\x88\x98\xec\xa4\x80\xec\x9d\x84 \xea\xb2\xb0\xec\xa0\x95\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xea\xb2\x83\xec\x9d\x84 \xea\xb6\x8c\xec\x9e\xa5\xed\x95\x9c\xeb\x8b\xa4. 
\xeb\xa0\x88\xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xb8\x94\xec\x9d\xb4 \xec\x97\x86\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\x84\xa4\xec\x9e\x84\xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x8e\x98\xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x8a\xa4\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\x95\x84\xec\xa7\x81 \xed\x8f\x89\xea\xb0\x80\xeb\x90\x98\xec\xa7\x80 \xec\x95\x8a\xec\x95\x98\xec\x9d\x8c\xec\x9d\x84 \xed\x91\x9c\xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x95\xb4\xec\x95\xbc \xed\x95\x9c\xeb\x8b\xa4.

\xeb\xaa\xa8\xeb\x93\xa0 \xeb\x84\xa4\xec\x9e\x84\xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x8e\x98\xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x8a\xa4\xec\x9d\x98 \xeb\xaa\xa8\xeb\x93\xa0 \xec\x9b\x8c\xed\x81\xac\xeb\xa1\x9c\xeb\x93\x9c\xec\x97\x90 \xeb\x8f\x99\xec\x9d\xbc\xed\x95\x9c \xeb\xb3\xb4\xec\x95\x88 \xec\x9a\x94\xea\xb5\xac \xec\x82\xac\xed\x95\xad\xec\x9d\xb4 \xec\x9e\x88\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\x8b\x9c\xeb\x82\x98\xeb\xa6\xac\xec\x98\xa4\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c, 
\xed\x8c\x8c\xeb\x93\x9c \xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x81\x90\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x8b\xb0 \xeb\xa0\x88\xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xb8\x94\xec\x9d\x84 \xeb\x8c\x80\xeb\x9f\x89\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c \xec\xa0\x81\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\xa0 \xec\x88\x98 \xec\x9e\x88\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\xb0\xa9\xeb\xb2\x95\xec\x9d\x84 \xeb\xb3\xb4\xec\x97\xac\xec\xa3\xbc\xeb\x8a\x94 [\xec\x98\x88\xec\x8b\x9c](/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-admission/#applying-to-all-namespaces)\xeb\xa5\xbc 
\xec\xa0\x9c\xea\xb3\xb5\xed\x95\x9c\xeb\x8b\xa4.

### \xec\xb5\x9c\xec\x86\x8c \xea\xb6\x8c\xed\x95\x9c \xec\x9b\x90\xec\xb9\x99 \xec\x88\x98\xec\x9a\xa9

\xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x83\x81\xec\xa0\x81\xec\x9d\xb8 \xea\xb2\xbd\xec\x9a\xb0 \xeb\xaa\xa8\xeb\x93\xa0 \xeb\x84\xa4\xec\x9e\x84\xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x8e\x98\xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x8a\xa4\xec\x9d\x98 \xeb\xaa\xa8\xeb\x93\xa0 \xed\x8c\x8c\xeb\x93\x9c\xea\xb0\x80 `\xec\xa0\x9c\xed\x95\x9c\xeb\x90\x9c` \xec\xa0\x95\xec\xb1\x85\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\x9a\x94\xea\xb5\xac \xec\x82\xac\xed\x95\xad\xec\x9d\x84 \xec\xb6\xa9\xec\xa1\xb1\xed\x95\xa0 
\xea\xb2\x83\xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\x8b\xa4. \xea\xb7\xb8\xeb\x9f\xac\xeb\x82\x98 \xec\x9d\xbc\xeb\xb6\x80 \xec\x9b\x8c\xed\x81\xac\xeb\xa1\x9c\xeb\x93\x9c\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\x8b\xb9\xed\x95\x9c \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9c\xa0\xeb\xa1\x9c \xec\x8a\xb9\xea\xb2\xa9\xeb\x90\x9c \xea\xb6\x8c\xed\x95\x9c(elevated privilege)\xec\x9d\xb4 \xed\x95\x84\xec\x9a\x94\xed\x95\x98\xeb\xaf\x80\xeb\xa1\x9c \xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\x8a\x94

\xec\x9a\xb0\xeb\xa6\xac\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\xbf\xa0\xeb\xb2\x84\xeb\x84\xa4\xed\x8b\xb0\xec\x8a\xa4 \xec\x98\xa4\xed\x94\x88\xec\x86\x8c\xec\x8a\xa4 \xec\xbb\xa4\xeb\xae\xa4\xeb\x8b\x88\xed\x8b\xb0\xec\x97\x90 \xec\xb7\xa8\xec\x95\xbd\xec\xa0\x90\xec\x9d\x84 \xeb\xb3\xb4\xea\xb3\xa0\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\xb3\xb4\xec\x95\x88 \xec\x97\xb0\xea\xb5\xac\xec\x9b\x90\xeb\x93\xa4\xea\xb3\xbc \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90\xeb\x93\xa4\xec\x97\x90\xea\xb2\x8c \xeb\xa7\xa4\xec\x9a\xb0 \xea\xb0\x90\xec\x82\xac\xed\x95\x98\xea\xb3\xa0 \xec\x9e\x88\xeb\x8b\xa4. \xeb\xaa\xa8\xeb\x93\xa0 \xeb\xb3\xb4\xea\xb3\xa0\xec\x84\x9c\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\xbb\xa4\xeb\xae\xa4\xeb\x8b\x88\xed\x8b\xb0 \xec\x9e\x90\xec\x9b\x90 \xeb\xb4\x89\xec\x82\xac\xec\x9e\x90\xeb\x93\xa4\xec\x97\x90 \xec\x9d\x98\xed\x95\xb4 \xec\xb2\xa0\xec\xa0\x80\xed\x9e\x88 \xec\xa1\xb0\xec\x82\xac\xeb\x90\x9c\xeb\x8b\xa4.

\xeb\x98\x90\xed\x95\x9c, \xeb\xb3\xb4\xec\x95\x88 \xec\x84\xb8\xeb\xb6\x80 \xeb\x82\xb4\xec\x9a\xa9\xea\xb3\xbc [\xeb\xaa\xa8\xeb\x93\xa0 \xec\xbf\xa0\xeb\xb2\x84\xeb\x84\xa4\xed\x8b\xb0\xec\x8a\xa4 \xeb\xb2\x84\xea\xb7\xb8 \xeb\xb3\xb4\xea\xb3\xa0\xec\x84\x9c](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/bug-report.yaml)\xeb\xa1\x9c \xeb\xb6\x80\xed\x84\xb0 \xec\x98\x88\xec\x83\x81\xeb\x90\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\x84\xb8\xeb\xb6\x80\xec\x82\xac\xed\x95\xad\xec\x9d\x84 [security@kubernetes.io](mailto:security@kubernetes.io)\xeb\xa1\x9c \xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xa9\x94\xec\x9d\xbc\xec\x9d\x84 \xeb\xb3\xb4\xeb\x82\xb8\xeb\x8b\xa4.

## \xeb\xb3\xb4\xec\x95\x88 \xec\xb7\xa8\xec\x95\xbd\xec\xa0\x90 \xeb\x8c\x80\xec\x9d\x91

\xea\xb0\x81 \xeb\xb3\xb4\xea\xb3\xa0\xec\x84\x9c\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\xb3\xb4\xec\x95\x88 \xeb\x8c\x80\xec\x9d\x91 \xec\x9c\x84\xec\x9b\x90\xed\x9a\x8c \xec\x9c\x84\xec\x9b\x90\xeb\x93\xa4\xec\x97\x90 \xec\x9d\x98\xed\x95\xb4 \xec\x9e\x91\xec\x97\x85\xec\x9d\xbc 3\xec\x9d\xbc \xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\x82\xb4\xec\x97\x90 \xec\x9d\xb8\xec\xa0\x95\xeb\x90\x98\xea\xb3\xa0 \xeb\xb6\x84\xec\x84\x9d\xeb\x90\x9c\xeb\x8b\xa4. \xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xa0\x87\xea\xb2\x8c \xed\x95\x98\xeb\xa9\xb4 [\xeb\xb3\xb4\xec\x95\x88 \xeb\xa6\xb4\xeb\xa6\xac\xec\x8a\xa4 \xed\x94\x84\xeb\xa1\x9c\xec\x84\xb8\xec\x8a\xa4](https://git.k8s.io/security/security-release-process.md#disclosures)\xea\xb0\x80 \xec\x8b\x9c\xec\x9e\x91\xeb\x90\x9c\xeb\x8b\xa4.

\xeb\xb3\xb4\xec\x95\x88 \xeb\x8c\x80\xec\x9d\x91 \xec\x9c\x84\xec\x9b\x90\xed\x9a\x8c\xec\x99\x80 \xea\xb3\xb5\xec\x9c\xa0\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\xaa\xa8\xeb\x93\xa0 \xec\xb7\xa8\xec\x95\xbd\xec\x84\xb1 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\xbf\xa0\xeb\xb2\x84\xeb\x84\xa4\xed\x8b\xb0\xec\x8a\xa4 \xed\x94\x84\xeb\xa1\x9c\xec\xa0\x9d\xed\x8a\xb8 \xeb\x82\xb4\xec\x97\x90 \xec\x9e\x88\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa9\xb0, \xeb\xac\xb8\xec\xa0\x9c\xeb\xa5\xbc \xed\x95\xb4\xea\xb2\xb0\xed\x95\xa0 \xed\x95\x84\xec\x9a\x94\xea\xb0\x80 \xec\x97\x86\xeb\x8a\x94 \xed\x95\x9c \xeb\x8b\xa4\xeb\xa5\xb8 \xed\x94\x84\xeb\xa1\x9c\xec\xa0\x9d\xed\x8a\xb8\xec\x97\x90 \xec\xa0\x84\xed\x8c\x8c\xeb\x90\x98\xec\xa7\x80 \xec\x95\x8a\xeb\x8a\x94\xeb\x8b\xa4.

\xeb\xb3\xb4\xec\x95\x88 \xeb\xac\xb8\xec\xa0\x9c\xea\xb0\x80 \xec\x8b\xac\xec\x82\xac\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c \xed\x99\x95\xec\x9d\xb8\xeb\x90\x9c \xec\x88\x98\xec\xa0\x95, \xeb\xa6\xb4\xeb\xa6\xac\xec\x8a\xa4 \xea\xb3\x84\xed\x9a\x8d\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c \xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\x8f\x99\xed\x95\xa8\xec\x97\x90 \xeb\x94\xb0\xeb\x9d\xbc \xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x8f\xac\xed\x84\xb0\xeb\xa5\xbc \xea\xb3\x84\xec\x86\x8d \xec\x97\x85\xeb\x8d\xb0\xec\x9d\xb4\xed\x8a\xb8\xed\x95\xa0 \xea\xb2\x83\xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\x8b\xa4.

## \xed\x8c\x8c\xeb\x93\x9c-\xec\x88\x98\xec\xa4\x80 \xeb\xb3\xb4\xec\x95\x88 \xea\xb2\xa9\xeb\xa6\xac

b"# Security Policy

## Supported Versions

| Version | Supported          |
| ------- | ------------------ |
| 2020.3f   | :white_check_mark: |

## Reporting a Vulnerability

Due to the nature of the project, it shouldn't compromise the user or the project, but if you find any vulnerability 
please report it as an issue so I can look into it. Templates exist for this already, so use them and follow
the instructions. If anything comes up, please contact me.

(Suggestions for fixes are very much welcome, and I'll look into them and create assist in the PR creation if necessary)
"

b"<!-- BEGIN MICROSOFT SECURITY.MD V0.0.8 BLOCK -->

## Security

Microsoft takes the security of our software products and services seriously, which includes all source code repositories managed through our GitHub organizations, which include [Microsoft](https://github.com/microsoft), [Azure](https://github.com/Azure), [DotNet](https://github.com/dotnet), [AspNet](https://github.com/aspnet), [Xamarin](https://github.com/xamarin), and [our GitHub organizations](https://opensource.microsoft.com/).

If you believe you have found a security vulnerability in any Microsoft-owned repository that meets [Microsoft's definition of a security vulnerability](https://aka.ms/opensource/security/definition), please report it to us as described below.

## Reporting Security Issues

**Please do not report security vulnerabilities through public GitHub issues.**

Instead, please report them to the Microsoft Security Response Center (MSRC) at [https://msrc.microsoft.com/create-report](https://aka.ms/opensource/security/create-report).

If you prefer to submit without logging in, send email to [secure@microsoft.com](mailto:secure@microsoft.com).  If possible, encrypt your message with our PGP key; please download it from the [Microsoft Security Response Center PGP Key page](https://aka.ms/opensource/security/pgpkey).

You should receive a response within 24 hours. If for some reason you do not, please follow up via email to ensure we received your original message. Additional information can be found at [microsoft.com/msrc](https://aka.ms/opensource/security/msrc). 

Please include the requested information listed below (as much as you can provide) to help us better understand the nature and scope of the possible issue:

  * Type of issue (e.g. buffer overflow, SQL injection, cross-site scripting, etc.)
  * Full paths of source file(s) related to the manifestation of the issue
  * The location of the affected source code (tag/branch/commit or direct URL)
  * Any special configuration required to reproduce the issue
  * Step-by-step instructions to reproduce the issue
  * Proof-of-concept or exploit code (if possible)
  * Impact of the issue, including how an attacker might exploit the issue

This information will help us triage your report more quickly.

If you are reporting for a bug bounty, more complete reports can contribute to a higher bounty award. Please visit our [Microsoft Bug Bounty Program](https://aka.ms/opensource/security/bounty) page for more details about our active programs.

## Preferred Languages

We prefer all communications to be in English.

## Policy

Microsoft follows the principle of [Coordinated Vulnerability Disclosure](https://aka.ms/opensource/security/cvd).

<!-- END MICROSOFT SECURITY.MD BLOCK -->
"

b'# Aptible Open Source Security Policies and Procedures

This document outlines security procedures and general policies for the Aptible open source projects as found on https://github.com/aptible.

  * [Reporting a Vulnerability](#reporting-a-vulnerability)
  * [Responsible Disclosure Policy](#responsible-disclosure-policy)

## Reporting a Vulnerability 

The Aptible team and community take all security vulnerabilities
seriously. Thank you for improving the security of our open source software. We appreciate your efforts and responsible disclosure and will make every effort to acknowledge your contributions.

Report security vulnerabilities by emailing the Aptible security team at:
    
    security@aptible.com

Security researchers can also privately report security vulnerabilities to repository maintainers using the GitHub "Report a Vulnerability" feature. [See how-to here](https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/security-advisories/guidance-on-reporting-and-writing/privately-reporting-a-security-vulnerability#privately-reporting-a-security-vulnerability).

The Aptible team will acknowledge your email within 24 business hours and send a detailed response within 48 business hours indicating the next steps in handling your report. The Aptible security team will keep you informed of the progress and may ask for additional information or guidance.

## Responsible Disclosure Policy

Please see Aptible's Responsible Disclosure Policy here: https://www.aptible.com/legal/responsible-disclosure/
'

b"<!-- BEGIN MICROSOFT SECURITY.MD V0.0.8 BLOCK -->

## Security

Microsoft takes the security of our software products and services seriously, which includes all source code repositories managed through our GitHub organizations, which include [Microsoft](https://github.com/microsoft), [Azure](https://github.com/Azure), [DotNet](https://github.com/dotnet), [AspNet](https://github.com/aspnet), [Xamarin](https://github.com/xamarin), and [our GitHub organizations](https://opensource.microsoft.com/).

If you believe you have found a security vulnerability in any Microsoft-owned repository that meets [Microsoft's definition of a security vulnerability](https://aka.ms/opensource/security/definition), please report it to us as described below.

## Reporting Security Issues

**Please do not report security vulnerabilities through public GitHub issues.**

Instead, please report them to the Microsoft Security Response Center (MSRC) at [https://msrc.microsoft.com/create-report](https://aka.ms/opensource/security/create-report).

If you prefer to submit without logging in, send email to [secure@microsoft.com](mailto:secure@microsoft.com).  If possible, encrypt your message with our PGP key; please download it from the [Microsoft Security Response Center PGP Key page](https://aka.ms/opensource/security/pgpkey).

You should receive a response within 24 hours. If for some reason you do not, please follow up via email to ensure we received your original message. Additional information can be found at [microsoft.com/msrc](https://aka.ms/opensource/security/msrc). 

Please include the requested information listed below (as much as you can provide) to help us better understand the nature and scope of the possible issue:

  * Type of issue (e.g. buffer overflow, SQL injection, cross-site scripting, etc.)
  * Full paths of source file(s) related to the manifestation of the issue
  * The location of the affected source code (tag/branch/commit or direct URL)
  * Any special configuration required to reproduce the issue
  * Step-by-step instructions to reproduce the issue
  * Proof-of-concept or exploit code (if possible)
  * Impact of the issue, including how an attacker might exploit the issue

This information will help us triage your report more quickly.

If you are reporting for a bug bounty, more complete reports can contribute to a higher bounty award. Please visit our [Microsoft Bug Bounty Program](https://aka.ms/opensource/security/bounty) page for more details about our active programs.

## Preferred Languages

We prefer all communications to be in English.

## Policy

Microsoft follows the principle of [Coordinated Vulnerability Disclosure](https://aka.ms/opensource/security/cvd).

<!-- END MICROSOFT SECURITY.MD BLOCK -->
"
